DOC.HEAD: Existing Home Sales at Quickest Pace in Nearly a Year
Eds: SUBS 14th gaf pvs to CORRECT sales rate in Midwest to 950,000 from 450,000; PICKS UP 15th graf pvs, `All of...; Also moved on general news wires
DOC.TEXT: Sales of existing homes advanced 3.2 percent in November, with a big jump in activity in the South spurring the fastest growth rate in 11 months, a real estate trade group reported Wednesday. The National Association of Realtors said sales of existing single-family homes rose to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.59 million units last month, the best performance since sales reached a rate of 3.92 million units in December 1988. The 3.2 percent October-to-November sales increase followed a 1.1 percent decline in October. It was the biggest percentage gain since a 4.5 percent rise in August. Analysts credited declining mortgage rates for the upturn in sales activity. But they said that housing sales presented a mixed picture with some areas of the country such as the Northeast hurting because of a rapid surge in prices in the past several years. ``Some large, high-cost markets have experienced some softening this year. However, many smaller, secondary cities are quite strong,'' said John Tuccillo, chief economist for the realtors. He said the disparity in sales between high-cost areas and more moderately priced markets should continue in 1990. Sluggish sales in high-cost areas has prompted some fears of a coming housing recession, but Norman D. Flynn, president of the realtors group, said the doomsayers would be proven wrong. ``People who are predicting hard times for housing are not considering how much prices rose in high-cost areas over the past few years,'' said Flynn, who cited the Northeast, where the median price is up 85 percent from five years ago. Tuccillo predicted that falling mortgage rates would continue to boost home sales in coming months. The national average for fixed-rate mortgages dipped to 9.69 percent last week, down from a high last March of 11.22 percent. The median price for homes sold in November edged up 0.4 percent to $93,000. The West pulled ahead of the Northeast in November as the region with the highest priced homes, recording a median resale cost of $150,200 last month. The Northeast was second with a median price of $145,800, followed by the South at $82,400 and the Midwest at $70,900. The median is the point at which half the homes sold for more and half for less. In November, the sales increase was led by a 9.2 percent jump in sales in the South, where homes were sold at an annual rate of 1.42 million units in November. Sales were up 3.2 percent in the West to an annual rate of 640,000 units. The Northeast posted a 1.7 percent rise to an annual rate of 590,000 units. Sales in the Midwest were down 4 percent to an annual rate of 950,000 units. All of the percentage comparisons were with October sales rates. When compared to sales in November 1988, the Midwest had a small increase of 1.1 percent while activity in the South was up by 0.7 percent. However, sales in the Northeast are down 13.2 percent when compared to a year ago while sales in the West are off by 5.9 percent compared to November 1988.
